topic.title: Information typing
topic.shortdesc: Information typing is the practice of identifying types of topics that contain distinct kinds information, such as concept, task, and reference information. Topics that answer different reader questions (How ...? What is ...?) can be categorized with different information types. The base information types provided by various DITA specializations, i.e., technical communication, machine industry, learning and training, and so on, provide starter sets that can be adopted immediately by many technical and business-related organizations.

body.p:
Classifying information by type helps authors
develop new information more consistently
ensure that the correct structure is used for closely related kinds of information (retrieval-oriented structures like tables for reference information and simple sequences of steps for task information)
avoid mixing content types, thereby losing reader focus
separate supporting concept and reference information from tasks so that it can be read if needed and ignored if not
eliminate unimportant or redundant detail
identify common and reusable subject matter

Information typing has a long history of use in the technical documentation field to improve information quality. It is based on extensive research and experience, including Robert Horn's Information Mapping and Hughes Aircraft's STOP (Sequential Thematic Organization of Proposals) technique.

Information types in DITA are expressed as topic types. The core topic types provided by DITA specializations, such as the technical communication and learning and training specializations, can be used as a basis for further specialization. Additional information types that require unique structures and semantics can be supported by developing specialized topic types that define the specific markup and structural rules required.
Note that many additional topic types included in DITA 1.1 and 1.2 are not necessarily closely connected with traditional Information Mapping.
